content: The "Teachers and First Responders Back to Work Act of 2012" authorizes grants to States for preventing teacher layoffs and creating jobs in public education for the 2012-2014 school years. The "Teachers and First Responders Back to Work Act of 2012" authorizes grants to States for preventing teacher layoffs and creating jobs in public education for the 2012-2014 school years. From the appropriated amount, the Secretary reserves funds to provide assistance to outlying areas and the Secretary of the Interior for activities consistent with the title. The Secretary may determine terms and conditions for activities under this title. Not more than 1/2 of 1 percent is reserved for assistance to the Secretary of the Interior for activities in schools funded by the Bureau of Indian Education. Up to $2,000,000 may be reserved for administration and oversight for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. Award amounts for each State will be determined by the Secretary. Up to $2,000,000 may be reserved for administration and oversight for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The Secretary shall determine award amounts for each State based on population ratios of individuals aged 5 through 17. The Secretary allocates funds to each State based on population ratios of individuals aged 5 through 17 and total population. If a State does not receive a grant, reallocation may occur. The Secretary allocates funds to each State based on population ratios, with reallocation occurring if a State does not receive a grant. SEC. 103. STATE APPLICATION. The chief executive of a State must submit an application to the Secretary within 30 days of the enactment of the Act, containing required information and an assurance to maintain State support for education at a certain level for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The chief executive of a State must submit an application to the Secretary within 30 days of the enactment of the Act, ensuring State support for education at a certain level for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. This support can be maintained either at the same amount as in fiscal year 2011 or at a percentage of the State's total expenditures equal to or greater than the percentage provided in fiscal year 2011. The chief executive of a State must submit a letter to the Secretary within 30 days of the Act's enactment if they do not wish to receive a grant under this title. The Secretary may waive the requirement for a State to provide a certain level of support for education in fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The Act requires a State's chief executive to submit a letter to the Secretary if they do not want to receive a grant under this title. The Secretary has the authority to waive certain requirements for a State under exceptional circumstances or financial decline. SEC. 104. STATE GRANTS. Each State receiving a grant under this title must reserve 10% for State-funded early learning programs and 2% for administrative costs. The remaining funds are to be used for awards to local educational agencies for early childhood, elementary, and secondary public education support. After reserving funds for State-funded early learning programs and administrative costs, a State receiving a grant under this title must allocate the remaining funds to local educational agencies for early childhood, elementary, and secondary public education support through subgrants. A State receiving a grant under this title must distribute the remaining funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios, with 60 percent allocated proportionally and 40 percent distributed accordingly. The State allocates remaining grant funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios, with 40 percent distributed according to funds received under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The State allocates remaining grant funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios, with subgrants made available not later than 100 days after receiving the grant. The State must distribute grant funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios within 100 days. Grant funds cannot be used to establish or supplement a rainy-day fund. A State receiving a grant under this title cannot use the funds to establish, restore, supplement, or supplant State funds for rainy-day funds or debt obligations. SEC. 105. Local educational agency subgrants are to be used for retaining, recalling, or hiring employees for educational services. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 106. Early learning programs. SEC. 106. Early learning programs funded under this title must use funds for retaining, recalling, or hiring early childhood educators for providing early learning services. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 107. REPORTING. States receiving grants must report on fund usage and job support by September 30 of 2013 and 2014. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. Defines terms such as "local educational agency", "outlying area", "State educational agency", and "State-funded early learning program". SEC. 109 authorizes $30 billion for the grant program in fiscal years 2012 and 2013. TITLE II aims to prevent layoffs and create jobs for law enforcement officers and firefighters through funding to States and localities. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to make competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain firefighters and maintain resources for fire departments. The Secretary may waive certain requirements in the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act. Additional funds are authorized for these grants. The Secretary of Homeland Security can grant funds to fire departments for hiring and maintaining firefighters. The Secretary has the authority to waive specific requirements in the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act. An additional $1 billion is authorized for grants in fiscal years 2012 and 2013, with a portion reserved for administrative costs. SEC. 203. LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER GRANT PROGRAM. The Attorney General will provide competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain law enforcement officers under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. These grants are not subject to certain sections of the Act. Additional funds are authorized for these grants. The Attorney General will provide competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain law enforcement officers under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. An additional $4,000,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 for these grants, with a portion reserved for administrative costs.
